results.title: Regeneration = Behind the lines
results.creator_credit: Rafford Films, Norstar Entertainment, BBC, Scottish Arts Council Lottery Fund, Telefilm Canada, Allan Scott, Peter R Simpson and Gilles MacKinnon
results.brief_description: Set in Craiglockhart military hospital during World War I, this is based on a real life encounter between military psychologist Dr William Rivers (Jonathan Pryce), and the poet Siegfried Sassoon (James Wilby) who has been institutionalized in an attempt to undermine his public disapproval of the war. It is also about the young poet Wilfred Owen (Stuart Bunce), who with support from Sassoon, starts to write his great war poems. Gilles MacKinnon’s highly praised adaptation of Pat Barker’s novel is a powerful study of war and its long reaching effects.

results.title: Regarding Henry
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Scott Rudin and Mike Nichols
results.brief_description: Harrison Ford stars as Henry Turner, a successful but ruthless New York lawyer who must win at any cost, even at the expense of his family. A single, freakish gunshot brings Henry’s world crashing down as he is left incapacitated and with no memory of the life he used to lead. Now, faced with starting over, Henry will learn the painful truth about his life and rediscover the family he never really had. Also starring Annette Bening as Henry’s long-suffering wife, this thought provoking film questions the importance of money over family and ultimately - the price of happiness.

results.title: Regain = Harvest
results.brief_description:
A poacher, wishing for fatherhood, coaxes an itinerant girl away from her simple knifegrinder companion and sets up house with her in a deserted village which they bring back to life. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide. A darker side to Marcel Pagnol’s work drew on an older Mediterranean culture, that of the rural drama reflected in ‘Jofroi’ (1933), ‘Angele’ (1934) and ‘Regain/Harvest’ (1937). These melodramas were grounded in the same archaic patriarchal values as the trilogy, but they swapped theatricality for location shooting and have been recognised as influential on neo-realism.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. The companion to French cinema. BFI Publishing, 1996. =Held in our collection.

Credits: Director, writer, Marcel Pagnol ; photography, Willy ; music, Arthur Honegger.
Cast: Gabriel Gabrio, Fernandel, Orane Demazis, Edouard Delmont, Marguerite Moreno, Robert Le Vigan.

results.title: Refuge England
results.creator_credit: BFI, Robert Vas and Laszlo Marton
results.brief_description: A study in the loneliness of a stranger confronted with the vastness of a foreign city. A first impression of London is captured with a fresh, eager eye, and the gradual realisation of their lack of concern is beautifully established in a series of encounters with a newspaper seller, a policeman, and most effectively of all, a man mowing his lawn in a suburban street.

results.title: Refrigeration and air conditioning
results.brief_description: Illustrates the basic concept that evaporation is a cooling process. A model refrigerator with plastic coils shows how, through a continuous cycle of evaporation and condensation of a refrigerant, heat is absorbed from inside the insulated box and released outside. The same principles are seen in air conditioning systems, and convection currents are illustrated.

results.title: Refractories from earth and sea
results.brief_description: Tells the story of an industrial enterprise engaged in the production of refractories - the heat resistant materials used in the construction of equipment required to contain fire and heat, and the many uses of refractories, in lining furnaces, firegrates and atomic power-plants

results.title: Reform school girl
results.creator_credit: American International Pictures (AIP), Robert J. Gurney, Samuel Z Arkoff and Edward Bernds
results.brief_description: Aimed at a teenage audience, “Reform school girl” is a redemptive tale about a mixed-up teenager, Donna Price, who after her involvement in a fatal car crash, is shipped off to reform school. There she is witness to the out-of-kilter lives of wayward girls and she recognises her choice between revealing the truth of the night of the crash, and perishing behind bars. At times this B-movie juvenile-delinquency drama is quite gritty and sordid, dealing with the themes of incest, manipulation and moral corruption.

results.title: Reflections: Ireland
results.creator_credit: Viscom Productions, Grania O'Shannon, John Spencer and Patrick Carey
results.brief_description: This beautiful atmospheric film shows various aspects of an Irish landscape, which is particularly emphasised by rivers, wind and sea. Interesting use of sounds, eg birds chirping, water flowing and the use of traditional Irish folk music played by Paddy Moloney and the Chieftains.

results.title: Reflections: a Japanese folk tale
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Thomas Smith
results.brief_description: In a tale designed to probe the many facets of perception, a young man buys a box with a mirrored bottom and sees in it the face of his dead father. On opening the box his wife sees a young rival and a holy woman sees another holy woman. Are our own perceptions distorted by self-images? Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
